Identifying Characteristics: Centrally marked opercula Approximately 6-7 whorls with clear and smooth growth lines as adults (2-3 whorls as juveniles)
Inner coloration is white or pale blue
Adults exhibit olive green, greenish brown, brown or reddish brown shell coloration
Size: Adults can be up to 65mm
Biology: Ovoviviparous species—females bear the most young in the 4th and 5th years living
Sexual reproduction Females live up to 5 years, males live up to 3 years
Young are born typically from June to October in shallow waters
Females migrate to deeper waters for the winter
Diet: Generally feeds non-selectively on organic and inorganic bottom material
Also feeds on benthic and epiphytic algae (mostly by scraping)—diatoms are probably the most nutritious food it feeds on in eastern North America
Habitat: Prefers slow-moving freshwater rivers, streams, and lakes with soft, muddy or silt-y bottoms
Range: Native: East Asia—ranging from the tropics of Indochina to northern China and southeast Asia to Japan and eastern Russia
Invasive: North America—Canada, Unites States (CA, CT, MA, MD, NH, NJ, NY, PA, RI, ME, VA, ID, MI, IN, OH, WI)
